Award.AwardTitle: Self-Consistent Studies of Particle Acceleration In and Radiation Emission From Relativistic Outflows of GRBs
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to broaden our understanding of high-energy astrophysical phenomena, such as particle acceleration and radiation emission, in application to gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), which are among the most energetic events known in the universe. The physical processes involved are closely related and Dr. Medvedev will investigate their connections using first principles of theoretical analysis, dedicated numerical simulation, and comparison with observational data.

Broader impacts of the work include training of graduate and undergraduate students, and outreach via development of an internet resource which will explain to non-experts the ideas and the current status of the physics of collisionless shocks and relevant processes such as radiation emission and particle acceleration in application to gamma-ray bursts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Gamma Ray Bursts (or GRBs, for short) are the most violent phenomenon in the universe. Their brightness is so high that they are seen accross the universe. Most of them are so far away that we can learn about them only from their brighness pattern (light curve) and photon energy distribution (spectrum). In the course of our investication, we have explored the conditions pertinent to the acceleration of charged particles and the radiation they produce, which is ultimately detected by our observatories.

Our investigation is the first self-consistent fundamental study of the inter-relation of these two phenomena -- particle acceleration and radiation production -- in the violent environments of GRBs. These environments, called collisionless shocks, possess rapidly-varying small-scale electromagnetic fields (turbulence). We found out that there is deep connection between particle traansport (diffusion and acceleration) and the observed radiation from them in such fields. Our theoretical results are fully confirmed with thate-of-the-art numerical simulation of particle transport and radiation. The obtained results thus provide a unique and novel way to understand the enigmatic phenomenon of GRBs. 

Furthermore, the results of this progect are of fundamental importance for astrophysics, beyound the GRB astrophysics. They can be applicable to other astrophysical sources with high-amplitude small-scale electromagnetic turbulence, such as supernova explosions and their remnants, shocks, magnetic field reconnection regions, turbulence in the interstellar medium and others.

At last but not least, conditions produced in laboratory experiments with the most powerful lasers are very similar to those in GRBs, as we demonstrated earlier. We then proposed to create a "GRB in a lab" -- an initiative within Laboratory Astrophysics program. In this project, we demonstrated the feasibility of such a novel approach to study and diagnose laboratory plasmas. We have also shown that turbulent fields may affect the performance of laser-plasma and inertial fusion experiments.
